awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a critical challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches.  The growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have cybersecurity knowledge and skills. To address this national challenge in education and workforce development, the CyberWatch West Resource Center will assist colleges around the nation with the development and improvement of educational programs in cybersecurity. This Advanced Technological Education (ATE) resource center will build on the foundation that has been laid by the CyberWatch West ATE regional center (NSF Awards DUE-1104278, DUE-1361636, and DUE-1500375), the Catalyzing Computing and Cybersecurity in Community Colleges (C5) project (NSF Award DGE-1548315), and the National Security Agency/Department of Homeland Security "Centers of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense National Resource Center" (CNRC) at Whatcom Community College.

The CyberWatch West Resource Center will support colleges that want to develop or enhance their cybersecurity education programs and strengthen the cybersecurity workforce through four interrelated efforts: (1) Expand participation in the Centers of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense National Resource Center program through mentor-mentee training for two-year and four-year institutions. This work will directly complement the NSA-funded CNRC at Whatcom Community College. (2) Catalog and disseminate, through an online repository, resources that strengthen cybersecurity courses and curricula in higher education, including instructional modules developed under a previous NSF-funded project. (3) Expand business/industry-academic partnerships nationwide and build regional cybersecurity communities that engage business/industry with cybersecurity faculty and students. (4) Disseminate resources that aid faculty mentoring and professional development, and student development. Through these efforts, the center aims to: promote the standardization of cybersecurity content in college programs; build awareness of community college cybersecurity programs and the qualifications of students who earn an associate degree or certificate in a community college program; address the national need for cybersecurity workers across all sectors, including government, defense, healthcare, and commerce; diversify the talent pool from which employers can draw their cybersecurity workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The CyberWatch West Resource Center was established to assist U.S. colleges in developing cybersecurity educational programs and to strengthen the nation's cybersecurity workforce through four interrelated goals:

1. Expand participation in the National Centers of Academic Excellence (CAE) program through mentor/mentee training for two-year and four-year institutions;

2. Serve as a dissemination agent for resources that strengthen cybersecurity curriculum in higher education, including instructional modules developed under the C5 project;

3. Improve participation, expand partnerships with industry nationwide and build regional cybersecurity communities through industry networking events; and

4. Facilitate dissemination of faculty mentoring and student development resources.

During the grant period, the Center was renamed to the National Cybersecurity Training and Education Center (NCyTE).

NCyTE and its many partners accomplished these goals through a variety of strategies.

1. Expansion of WCC Mentor/Mentee Support program:

This program introduced a structured process for colleges to follow to achieve the Center of Academic Excellence in Cyberdefense designation (awarded by the National Security Agency and its partners). Mentors were provided to colleges to assist during the application process. During the grant period, the number of institutions receiving the designation increased from 141 in 2017 to over 400 in 2022, and the number of community colleges grew from 25 in 2017 to 137 in 2022.

2. Dissemination of materials:

NCyTE introduced a substantial collection of curricular resources, uploading the vast majority to Clark.Center (a curriculum repository), including cybersecurity lessons and modules developed under the C5 project. NCyTE disseminated these free, online resources for secondary teachers and college faculty also through NCyTE's YouTube channel, CodeHS, ncyte.net and through conference presentations and professional development workshops. Through these efforts, the new AP Computer Science Principles: Cybersecurity course developed in partnership with CodeHS.realized  2,541 enrollments as of September 2022.

NCyTE's YouTube Channel has 650 subscribers, 58 titles, and over 28,000 views. Titles include: Introduction to Small Unmanned Aerial System, Introduction to Cyber Supply Chain Attacks and Risk Management, Maritime Transportation System Cyber Attacks and Mitigation Strategies. 

Additional curriculum, faculty resources, and navigation links to Clark.Center, CodeHS, and NCyTE's YouTube channel are found at ncyte.net.  

3. Industry partnerships:

The NCyTE industry Advisory Committee provided  guidance on NCyTE's efforts and support for initiatives, and input into an action plan for the future of cybersecurity education at community colleges (Future Directions Summit: 2022 held in June). Through Industry Night events sponsored by NCyTE, a model for supporting regional college and industry partnerships continued to be disseminated. One model event was the grand opening of a cyber range, which was developed through a public private partnership between NCyTE, Whatcom Community College and Anvil Corporation in Bellingham, WA. Another brought together educators and employers for a panel discussion on cybersecurity jobs in rural New Mexico, which continues to have potential for a much more substantial economic development project to fund a tribal cyber range for the Mescalero Apache tribe.  

4. Facilitated dissemination of faculty and student development resources.

NCyTE collaborated broadly to identify and support activities for students and faculty such as the annual Virtual Career Fair with over 1,000 participants in 2022 in collaboration with California State University San Bernardino, collaboration with Anvil Corporation to create a cyber range for students to complete internships and capstone projects as well as Anvil employees to test industrial control systems, and with NSA to provide mentoring for college faculty as they complete the CAE application.

NCyTE disseminated information on cybersecurity professional development and other opportunities for faculty and students across a variety of NCyTE platforms such as  membership meetings, workshops, newsletters, and social media.

 

Impacts:

The economic impact of the expansion of CAE mentor/mentee support can be substantial to CAE designated institutions and their surrounding regions. A recent study documented one college's CAE designation contributing toward a cumulated $16.3M in earnings and 948 jobs.  Achieving the CAE also ensures security standards at institutions, and cross-campus/cross disciplinary cybersecurity education for staff and faculty. Combined with enhanced industry partnerships that increase industry’s connections to robust sources of qualified employees, these efforts help to address the significant workforce gap of over 700,000 jobs and the security of the nation.

Through the dissemination of curricular resources, faculty mentoring and student development resources, high school and college students and instructors/faculty are provided with an expanded, robust library of easy-access, increasingly cross-disciplinary modular curriculum on current and emerging topics.  These resources, and activities increase the number of students exposed to cybersecurity concepts, careers, and employer expectations and opportunities. The curricular resources, help a growing number of instructors and faculty to easily augment existing courses with cybersecurity topics (or to create new courses), and to expose students to concepts that will help them succeed in cybersecurity careers, apply cybersecurity to other disciplines, and to live more secure daily lives--thus ultimately impacting the security of our nation.


Last Modified: 11/07/2022
Modified by: Corrinne Sande
